On 2/9/06, frank zou <frankz1998@...> wrote:
>
>  However, for commercial software development, is this (using Junit)
> still possible ?


I think Junit has merits for commercial development that wants good code.


* Will Junit-based testing make the project time longer or shorter ?
> Any hard statistic data ? ( Here I mean commercial project rather than
> open-source project. )


I think if Junit is used from the beginning it makes it go faster.

During development bugs have a harder time creeping in because the tests
protect the existing behavior.

With a test framework in place, when new bugs are found, the tests are
augmented to cover that case and you can can worry less about that bugs
coming back.

Well tested code makes integration faster because the tests are working
examples of how to use the API of a class.

Q/A should go faster because the underlying code has less bugs.

I'll speculate it makes production bug fixes alot faster and safer, but the
projects I've had to maintain have not had unit test coverage with
Junit (which sucks).


* One intersting point I found is that after Junit-based testing is
> introduced, programmers tend to use IDE debugger much less than
> before.  This would save lots of time. Is that true ?


This isn't true for me. I use the Junit tests within my IDE to exercise the
class I'm writing. running them from ant outside of the IDE is the safety
net.



* How can I convince managers and programmers that JUnit-based is
> really possible for commercial software development ? Any differnece
> from open-source projects ?


Lead by example. Start using it. Learn to use Junit to write code faster
than anyone else on the team -- and with fewer bugs.  Your boss will be
coming to you.

- Dan
